Graphical abstract Ternary CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst was synthesized through coprecipitation method and the effect of indium addition on the textural and catalytic performance was evaluated. The catalysts were tested at 50 atm and 250 °C in H2/CO/CO2, H2/CO and H2/CO2 feed. The presence of In2O3 resulted in structural promotions including enhanced BET and copper surface area, smaller copper crystals and increased oxygen vacancies. On the contrary, unexpected results were observed in catalytic activities in H2/CO/CO2 and H2/CO2 feeds. Pure In2O3 revealed the ability of direct hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. In addition, it was observed that the addition of palladium into the catalyst remarkably enhanced the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Keywords Methanol synthesis CO2hydrogenation Indium oxide Palladium 1 Introduction Nowadays climate pollution is one of the major problems and among the pollutants, CO2 is responsible for global warming due to its greenhouse effect. Many attempts have been performed to mitigate this greenhouse gas including capturing and storage or converting it to useful chemicals [1–8]. The conversion of CO2 to methanol is an interesting route to mitigate this greenhouse gas. Methanol is one of the ten most important raw materials in the world [9]. This raw material is synthesized by catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 and CO over Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 ternary catalysts at 50−100 bar and 250−300 °C [10]. It has been estimated that around 2/3 of the produced methanol in industrial conditions is obtained from the hydrogenation of CO2 and the rest of methanol is synthesized from hydrogenation of CO [11]. Any factor affecting CO2 and CO conversion will also change the methanol production. For instance, the addition of some metallic elements such as Zr, Cr, Mn, and Fe can influence the rate of methanol production and its selectivity [12]. CO2 hydrogenation plays an important role in methanol synthesis and higher conversion of CO2 can result in more methanol production. Recently, due to the enhancement of CO2 content in the atmosphere and its greenhouse role, different catalysts have been introduced to converting the CO2 to other chemicals [13]. The ternary Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts can be used in the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. These ternary catalysts show high activity in converting the CO2 into methanol. Based on recently reported results, In2O3 can effectively hydrogenate the CO2 to methanol with 100 % selectivity [14] and improves the progress of the reverse water-gas shift reaction [15]. Actually, In2O3 is a Lewis acid having oxygen deficiency on its crystalline structure [16]. These oxygen deficiencies could be a suitable active site for the chemically adsorbed gases. These outstanding features of In2O3 made us interested to investigate the influence of In2O3 addition into the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. In this investigation for the first time, we deal with the effect of In2O3 addition on the catalytic activity and textural properties of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 and its role in the hydrogenation of CO and CO2. In addition, we investigated the catalytic performances of In2O3 catalysts in both CO/CO2/H2 and CO2/H2 feeds and the effect of palladium addition on the In2O3 activity in CO2 hydrogenation was also investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Five catalysts with different In2O3 and Al2O3 contents were prepared based on the optimized formula (67.5 % CuO, 25 % ZnO, 7.5 % Al2O3) as reported in our previous study [17]. In summary, 1 M nitrate solution of Cu (NO3)2.3H2O, Zn(NO3)2.6H2O, Al(NO3)3.9H2O and In(NO3)3.9H2O was co-precipitated simultaneously with 1 M Na2CO3 solution at 70 °C and the pH value was kept constant at 7 during the co-precipitation process. The precipitate was aged for 1 h and the initial blue color of precipitate turned into green. Then the suspension was filtered and washed three times with deionized water to remove the Na+ ions followed by drying at 80 °C and calcination at 320 °C for 3 h. Pure In2O3 was prepared from calcination of In(OH)3 at 400 °C for 3 h. In a typical synthesis, In(OH)3 was prepared through precipitation of 1 M indium nitrate solution by ammonia until the pH reached to 8. After precipitation, the suspension was filtered and washed several times with deionized water and the washed filter cake was then dried at 110 °C overnight. Finally, the In(OH)3 precipitate was calcined at 400 °C for 3 h. Also, Pd/In2O3 (1 wt.% Pd) was prepared by impregnation of the catalyst support (In2O3) with an aqueous solution of palladium nitrate at room temperature. After that, the impregnated support was dried at 80 °C and then calcined at 350 °C. The chemical compositions of the catalysts are reported in Table 1 . 2.2 Characterization techniques The crystalline structures of both un-calcined and calcined powders were studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD) method using a PANalytical X’Pert-Pro X-ray diffractometer. Cu crystallite sizes were calculated using the well-known Scherrer equation: (1) L = K λ β C O S θ Where λ is the X-ray wavelength in nanometer (nm), β is the peak width of the diffraction peak profile at half-maximum height, and K is a constant related to crystallite shape, normally taken as 0.9. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis was performed in a gas adsorption analyzer (BELSORP mini II). The reduction behavior was determined through temperature programmed reduction (TPR) by a Chemisorb 2750 (Micromeritics) instrument. The Cu surface (SCu) area and its dispersion (D) were determined using N2O chemisorption analysis. At first step, all the copper content was reduced and the consumed hydrogen was denoted as X. After that, the temperature was decreased to 50 °C and a mixture of 95 % N2 and 5 % N2O oxidized the reduced Cu to Cu+. Finally, all the Cu+ was reduced to Cu at the second TPR and the consumed hydrogen was denoted as Y. Copper surface area and dispersion were calculated by the following equations: (2) SCu = 2 × Y × Nav/(X × MCu×1.4 × 1019) = 1353 × Y/X (m2/g) (3) D = (2 × Y/X) × 100 % Where Nav is the Avogadro’s number, MCu is the relative atomic mass of copper (63.456 g/mol), and 1.4 × 1019 is the copper atom surface density per square meter. CO2-TPD experiment was performed in a U-shaped quartz reactor in the same instrument as mentioned for TPR analysis. Firstly, the catalyst was reduced at 240 °C using a reducing gas stream containing 5 % H2 in Ar. After reduction, the helium was passed over the sample to remove the unreacted gases and moisture and the temperature was decreased to 50 °C. Finally, CO2 was introduced and passed over the sample for 2 h. After that, the helium was passed over the sample to remove the physically adsorbed CO2 and then the temperature increased to 1000 °C in a He atmosphere and the amount of desorbed CO2 was measured with a thermal conductivity detector. High-resolution transmission electron microscopic (HR-TEM) images were obtained on a JEM-2100UHR apparatus to study the surface morphology of the samples. Thermogravimetric (TG) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) was performed in a Netzsch STA 409 system in a static air atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The XPS (X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy) measurements were performed on an ESCALAB 220iXL (ThermoFisher Scientific) with monochromated AlKα radiation (E =1486.6 eV). Samples are prepared on a stainless steel holder with conductive double sided adhesive carbon tape. The electron binding energies were obtained with charge compensation using a flood electron source and referenced to the C1s peak of CC and C–H bonds at 284.8 eV. For quantitative analysis the peaks were deconvoluted with Gaussian-Lorentzian curves, the peak areas were divided by the transmission function of the spectrometer and a sensitivity factor obtained from the element specific Scofield factor. 2.3 Catalytic performance Catalytic performances were evaluated in a fixed-bed stainless steel reactor (i.d. = 10 mm) at 5.0 MPa and 250 °C. 1 g of the sieved catalyst particles (mesh 35–60) was loaded into the reactor. Prior to reaction, the catalyst particles were reduced in a gas mixture containing 5 % H2 in 95 % N2 at 240 °C and ambient pressure for 12 h. The feed gas (100 Nml/min) was introduced into the reactor and the products and unreacted gases were analyzed by an online gas chromatograph equipped with a three-column system connected to a couple of helium ionized detectors (HID). A primary separation takes place on a Q PLOT capillary column. Methanol, water, and CO2 were analyzed by a Q PLOT capillary column (30 m × 0.53 mm) while CO, H2 and methane were determined by a HP-MOLSIEV capillary column (30m × 0.53 mm) and a HID. The space time yield (STY) and selectivity data were obtained using the mass-balance method. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 X-ray diffraction Fig. 1 a–c show the XRD patterns of un-calcined and calcined In2O3 containing catalysts and pure In2O3, respectively. According to Fig. 1a, at higher In2O3 contents, smooth shift to higher 2θs corresponding to a lower d-spacing was observed. In addition, the catalyst with 5 % In2O3 has the lowest crystallinity. Malachite, rosasite, and aurichalcite were observed in the samples as the main phases. The sample without In2O3 (CZA-5) showed stronger aurichalcite diffraction peaks. The shift in XRD peaks for higher amounts of In2O3 can be attributed to the unit cell properties. The shift to higher angles is related to contraction of unit cell parameters and the shift to the lower angles is due to higher d-spacing. This is because of the average lowering of Jahn–Teller distortions of the MO6 building units in zincian malachite meaning that the more Zn incorporation to the zincian malachite system, the lower unit cell parameters and consequently the higher 2θ angles [18]. The corresponding d-spacing from the firs peak of calcined species was obtained 2.5211, 2.5287, 2.5338, 2.5159 Å for CZA-0, CZA-2.5, CZA-5, CZ-7.5, respectively. When both aluminum and indium are present in the sample the d-spacing values are higher than the samples containing just aluminum or indium. It means that Zn decoration for CZA-2.5 and CZA-5 are less than CZA-0 and CZ-7.5. The highest Zn incorporation was observed for CZ-7.5 according to calculated d-spacing. Hence, increasing the In2O3 up to 7.5 % has resulted in more Zn incorporation to the zincian malachite system. The XRD patterns of the calcined catalysts are shown in Fig. 1b. Based on the diffraction patterns, the samples with 2.5 and 5 % In2O3 (CZA-2.5 and CZA-5) showed lower crystallinity and it is expected to have lower crystallite sizes. Moreover, in 7.5 % In2O3 (CZ-7.5) the highest crystallinity was observed. The obtained crystallite sizes obtained by Scherrer equation were recorded in Table 2 . 3.2 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and pore size distribution Fig. 2 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms accompanied by the corresponding pore size distributions. All the samples showed IV type isotherm with type H3 hysteresis loop. The IV type isotherm is assigned to mesoporous structures and the type H3 hysteresis is characteristic for slit-shaped pores. The highest specific surface area (BET) was observed in the catalyst containing 2.5 % In2O3 (CZA-2.5) and the largest pore volume was observed in the sample without In2O3 (CZA-0). Also, the smallest pore diameter was observed for the sample without Al2O3 (CZ-7.5). Replacing the Al by indium atoms resulted in smaller pore volumes. In addition, the specific surface area decreased (except CZA-2.5) by replacing Al atoms. Actually, aluminum acts stronger than indium in structural promoting while both of Al2O3 and In2O3 are resistant to thermal sintering due to their high melting point temperatures. The widest pore size distribution was observed for 5 % In2O3 (CZA-5). The textural properties of the prepared catalysts are reported in Table 2. 3.3 Reduction behavior In order to evaluate the reduction behavior of the catalysts the temperature programmed reduction (TPR) analysis was conducted on the calcined catalysts and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . The TPR profiles of the samples were deconvoluted into three peaks qualitatively. Three deconvoluted peaks imply that more than one active Cu site exists in the samples [19]: highly dispersed CuO specimens, large particles with and without contact with ZnO species. The first reduction peak could be related to the surface CuO in direct contact with ZnO species. The second reduction peak is related to an intermediate layer (bulk-intermediate CuO) being directly influenced by ZnO due to several atomic layer distance, whereas the third peak is assigned to the reduction of the core layer of copper oxide (bulk-core CuO). According to TPR profiles, it can be observed that the high-temperature reduction peak was diminished by increasing in In2O3 content. It can be concluded that the presence of Al could influence the high temperature reduction peak. Based on the literature [20] in higher aluminum contents, reduction of catalyst takes place at higher temperatures. It means that part of copper atoms has a strong interaction with aluminum which in turn influences the high-temperature reduction peak. In the sample without In2O3 (CZA-0) the most intense of high-temperature peak was observed while for the sample without aluminum (CZ-7.5) the mentioned peak has the lowest intensity meaning that copper atoms have very low interactions with In2O3. Probably this interaction can influence both activity and stability. Another point is that in 2.5 and 5 % In2O3 (CZA-2.5 and CZA-5 respectively) the reduction temperature for all three peaks is lower than CZA-0 and CZ-7.5. In addition, three mentioned peaks are lower for CZA-0 compared to the CZ-7.5. It can be interpreted that aluminum has a stronger interaction with copper species and this issue can affect the reduction temperature, activity, and stability. 3.4 Thermal gravimetric and differential thermal analysis (TGA/DTA) To study the decomposition behavior of the catalysts during the calcination process, the TGA/DTA analysis was conducted and the results are shown in Fig. 4 . All the catalysts except of CZA-5 possessed the same decomposition patterns. For three samples, a single decomposition step with high-temperature shoulder is observed. Actually, the curves can be separated into three zones. The first zone between 80–100 °C is related to the removal of physically adsorbed water. The second weight loss in the temperature range of 190−210 °C could be assigned to the removal of hydroxyl groups and releasing carbon dioxide due to thermal decomposition and the third weight loss between 315–420 °C is attributed to the decomposition of hydroxycarbonates [21]. Based on the literature [22] zincian-malachite which is responsible for high active catalyst has a single weight loss along with high-temperature shoulder, but the georgeite phase (an amorphous form of zincian-malachite) has more than a single step weight loss. According to Fig. 4, CZA-5 illustrated a two-step weight loss. It means that some of the uncalcined precursors is in georgeite or amorphous form. Amorphous precursor will result in a less crystalline product. This issue can be observed in XRD patterns. CZA-5 has less crystallinity in both uncalcined and calcined powder. According to XRD and TGA/DTA results, the textural effect of In2O3 addition is stronger for CZA-5. Actually, in this sample, the presence of Indium atoms has prohibited the complete transition of georgeite to zincian-malachite which in turn influences the catalytic performance. Nevertheless, these results should be examined in the catalyst activity test. 3.5 N2O frontal chromatography The copper surface area was determined by N2O frontal chromatography. One of the most important factors determining the final activity is the copper surface area. Usually, the higher Cu surface area, the higher the catalytic activity. We observed that In2O3 addition resulted in higher Cu surface area. It means that the lowest Cu surface area was for CZA-0 and the highest Cu surface area belonged to CZ-7.5. Existing oxygen deficiencies and defects can impact the Cu surface area resulting in overestimated copper surface area. In reduction procedure, oxygen vacancies are originated at the surface of In2O3 [23] which in turn influence the determination of Cu surface area. Higher calculated Cu surface area for In2O3 containing catalysts is probably related to higher oxygen vacancies created during the reduction, Table 2. 3.6 Catalytic tests In order to investigate the performance of the catalysts, the catalytic tests were performed at 50 atm and 250 °C with a feed stream consisting of 80 vol.% H2, 10 vol.% CO, and 10 vol.% CO2. The catalytic test results and the stability of the catalysts during 1200 min time on stream are shown in Fig. 5 a and b respectively. In2O3 is an active species in CO2 hydrogenation and the addition of In2O3 increased the Cu surface area, Table 2. Based on these results, we expected to observe higher activity for the catalysts containing In2O3. However, surprisingly we observed a reverse trend. Based on the results in Fig. 5b, the activity of all catalysts declined with time on stream and the sample without In2O3 is the most active sample. The reverse trend of activity with the addition of In2O3 may be due to the fast sintering of active copper particles. The sintering of copper particles can be monitored by XRD and N2O frontal chromatography. From the XRD pattern using Scherrer equation the Cu particle size after stability test for the CZA-0 was obtained 19 nm (fresh =8.8 nm) and the corresponding size for CZ-7.5 (without aluminum) was 21 nm (fresh =9.4 nm) meaning that: dCu for CZA-7.5(fresh), CZA-7.5 (used) > CZA-0 (fresh), CZA-0(used). In addition, the copper surface area reached to 23.15 m2/g (fresh = 38.89 m2/g) for CZA-0 at the end of run and a Cu surface area of 25.73 m2/g (fresh = 59.02 m2/g) was obtained for the CZ-7.5, indicating that both the crystalline growth and copper surface area are higher for CZ-7.5 reflecting the lower stabilizing effect of In2O3. The lower stability for indium containing catalysts is because of its inability to form an integrated atomic network to stabilize the active copper particles. To examine this hypothesis, we synthesized aluminum hydroxide similar to indium hydroxide and calcined both of them at 350 °C. The XRD patterns of both samples are shown in Fig. 6 a and b. It is seen that in the same calcination temperature the indium hydroxide converted to a crystalline In2O3 while the XRD pattern for aluminum hydroxide showed a relatively amorphous structure. Hence, one of the main reasons for the decrease in the activity is the indium inability to form an amorphous network to stabilize the active centers. Another reason may be assigned to different structures formed during the synthesis. According to XRD and TG results, some different hydroxycarbonate structures were observed in CZA-5 (5 % In2O3) resulting in a more amorphous structure and consequently lower sizes of copper oxide nanoparticles. Based on the XRD and TG results, the influence of the indium on the catalyst structure is more obvious. The ABF and HAADF-STEM images of the CZA-0 and CZA-5 catalysts are presented to find out the difference between indium-free and indium containing samples, Fig. 7 a–h. For CZA-0 the specimen showed small crystallites. As the crystallites have sintered quite strongly and thereby formed larger agglomerates, usually the images are formed by projection through multiple crystallites making Moiré fringes quite dominant. This issue is seen in Fig. 7b. Also, CuO and ZnO crystallites are seen as discreet crystallites in a disordered matrix (Fig. 7a). Likely disordered matrix hinders the sintering of active crystallites; because such disordered matrix can separate the crystallites from each other and boosts the stability. Al2O3 was detected as a distinct amorphous phase (Fig. 7c). Fig.7e–h are related to CZA-5. This specimen shows two distinct structure types. One consists of small crystallites and the other of larger round shaped and grown together rather porous structure. This second structure is also quite beam sensitive thereby hindering high-resolution imaging. Most probably, this beam sensitive structure is uncalcined amorphous georgeite. More attention to ABF- STEM, as presented in Fig. 7f and h, the catalyst consists of an amorphous matrix phase wherein sub-2 nm crystallites are embedded into a disconnected low ordered crystalline material exhibiting clear lattice fringes. Unlike the CZA-0, discrete crystallites of CuO and ZnO are not seen in ABF and HAADF-STEM images. Also, Moiré fringes were not observed for CZA-5. In comparison, CZA-5 showed lower crystallinity than CZA-0 and also this issue is consistent with XRD and TG results. In addition to TEM results, the XPS analysis was performed and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . XPS data showed that all the components are in oxidic phases. The peak at 953.5 eV with a strong satellite shake-up is related to Cu2+. Usually, the shake-up satellite peak appears for d9 electronic configuration in the ground state, i.e. the copper is in cationic Cu2+ [24]. Zinc has a very small binding energy shift from metal to oxide; therefore, one can use the Zn LMM region where the peak position clearly identifies ZnO. The observed peak around 498.5 eV is related to ZnO. Also, two peaks between 1015–1050 eV belong to ZnO. Different types of carbon originated from sodium carbonate is seen in the fitted diagram for CZA-0. Fitted XPS diagram for O1s shows three types of oxygen. Lower binding energy peak could be assigned to the O2− in lattice while medium and high energy peak could be attributed to adsorbed OH- and low oxygen coordination, respectively [25]. High binding energy for Al2s indicates oxidic nature of aluminum. Below 100 eV binding energies, the overlap of Al2p, Cu2p, and Zn3p takes place. The XPS peaks for two samples are nearly similar but the similar peaks for CAZ-5 have shifted a little toward lower binding energies wherein this phenomenon is the result of indium exertion to the catalyst. In addition, low oxygen coordination peak for CZA-5 is sharper compared to the other peaks meaning that the oxygen vacancies are more in the presence of indium oxide. The observed peak at 444 eV is the typical binding energy for In2O3. It is hard to distinguish between the metal and the oxide but the peak shape, position and the absence of loss features at higher binding energies indicate the presence as an oxide. Also, the peaks at lower binding energies might be originated in differential charging effects. We found from XPS data that all the components in both samples are in oxidic phase and concentration of oxygen vacancies is higher for CZA-5. Nevertheless, lower activity of In2O3 containing catalyst still has not been clarified. While the addition of indium oxide resulted in some structural improvements including the increased copper surface area and oxygen vacancies and smaller CuO crystallite sizes, but the reason for its lower activity is still unknown. The catalytic tests were conducted using different feed compositions, CO/H2 (20:80) and CO2/H2 (20:80), and in both cases (except pure In2O3) the methanol formation was lower than CO/CO2/H2 feed. In CO/H2 feed the produced methanol was negligible. Actually, in CO/H2 feed the catalyst is deactivated because of the over-reduction copper [26]. We conducted the activity test in 20 % CO2 and 80 % H2 feed. In this test, methanol was produced but the production rate was lower compared to H2/CO/CO2 feed. In fact, the more oxidized surface obtained by CO2 is more active and stable than over reduced copper obtained by CO [26]. The activity trends along with their corresponding stabilities are seen in Fig. 9 a and b, respectively. Evaluating the three main reactions in methanol synthesis could be helpful. These reactions are: (4) CO + 2H2  ⇌  CH3OH (5) CO2 + 3H2  ⇌  CH3OH + H2O (6) CO + H2O  ⇌  CO2 + H2 To investigate the In2O3 effect on the mentioned reactions and to find out the main reason of different activities, STY diagrams for CZA-0 (Indium-free) and CZ-7.5 (aluminum free) along with their CO and CO2 conversion diagrams plus H2O production during reaction time are presented in Fig. 10 . More attention to Fig. 10a and a1 and Table 2 reveals that STY and CO conversion for CZA-0 are severely correlated together; since both of them follow the same trend. Also, based on Table 2, drastic drop in CO conversion corresponds to a drastic drop in STY meaning that the methanol production intensively depends on the CO hydrogenation. It can be interpreted that for CZA-0 in our reaction condition, CO hydrogenation to methanol takes place in higher rates than CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Another point is seen in CO2 conversion and H2O production diagrams during stability test. CO2 conversion and H2O production showed nearly the same trends. After 400 min, the CO2 conversion has reached to steady state clarifying that CO2 hydrogenation has reached to a constant rate. Moreover, H2O production smoothly decreased to a steady state. It demonstrates that CO2 hydrogenation (reaction 5) and water-gas shift (WGS) have reached to steady state conditions and CO2 hydrogenation is faster than WGS, but according to higher conversion of carbon monoxide (Table 2), CO hydrogenation (reaction 4) proceeds in higher rates. This issue is in accordance with the literature [27]. Based on the literature [28] CO2 is a primary source of methanol and methanol synthesis gradually shifted from CO2 to CO hydrogenation. Concisely, for indium-free sample, methanol production severely depends on the CO hydrogenation and WGS takes place simultaneously. For CZ-7.5 (aluminum free sample), a different regime is dominant. According to Fig. 10b and b2, methanol production and CO2 conversion during the stability test showed the same tend. While STY and CO2 conversion are in dropping trend, CO conversion has approached to steady state. Besides, produced methanol and CO conversion are lower for CZ-7.5. The same trend of STY and CO2 conversion and lower CO conversion along with the lower amount for CZA-0 implies that in this case CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is dominant and CO hydrogenation is faster than CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. It means that in the presence of indium, hydrogenation regime has changed from CO hydrogenation to CO2 hydrogenation. In addition, H2O production has reached the steady state meaning that the production and consumption of water take place in the same rate. This balance arises from CO2 hydrogenation to methanol and reverse water-gas shift (RWGS). Since surface adsorption on the reduced copper for CO2 is stronger than CO [27], likely indium has changed the CO2 adsorption. To examine this hypothesis, we conducted CO2-TPD on reduced catalysts. Fig. 11 presents the CO2-TPD results for the prepared catalysts. Three samples show three desorption peaks and two samples showed two desorption peaks. All low-temperature peaks could be assigned to physical adsorption of CO2 [29]. CZA-0 to CZA-5 showed medium and relatively high-temperature desorption peaks. Pure In2O3 and CZ-7.5 showed low and high-temperature desorption peaks. It can be found from the TPD profiles that the increment in indium content moved the high-temperature desorption peak to higher temperatures. This indicates that CO2 adsorption is stronger in the presence of indium and the medium temperature desorption peaks have vanished for CZ-7.5 and pure In2O3. In In2O3, oxygen deficiencies affect the CO2-TPD. In fact, the basicity nature of the surface has been changed in the presence of indium and consequently, this difference in CO2 adsorption has changed the CO and CO2 hydrogenation regime. CO2 and CO hydrogenation to methanol seems to occur on different catalytic sites: CO hydrogenation proceeds through oxidized Cu sites while metallic Cu is necessary for CO2 hydrogenation. Actually, methanol is formed from CO when the surface is majorly covered by Cu+ and when the metallic Cu covers the surface the main source of methanol is CO2 [30]. From one hand, CO2 oxidizes the surface Cu to Cu2O and then CO and H2 easily reduce Cu2O to Cu and from the other hand, H2O and CO2 stabilize the Cu+. From this point of view, methanol is synthesized from carbon monoxide or carbon dioxide depending on the ratio of Cu+/Cu ratio [30,31]. Besides, higher CO2 amounts in the feed suppresses the methanol production due to strong adsorption of CO2 on the Cu surface [27]. In our experiment, the H2/CO/CO2 feed was the same for all the samples but CZA-0 showed the highest activity and CZ-7.5 and pure In2O3 showed the lowest activities. Based on the CO2-TPD of the reduced catalysts, strong adsorption of CO2 in indium containing samples has changed the hydrogenation regime from CO to CO2 and consequently lower methanol production was observed due to a lower rate of hydrogenation of CO2 than CO [27]. More attention to Fig. 5 discloses that by increasing the In2O3 from 2.5 to 5 wt.% a drastic drop was observed in catalytic activity. This drastic drop in catalytic activity is the result of a drastic drop in CO conversion (Table 2) which in turn verifies the higher rate of CO hydrogenation to methanol. The results indicated that the CO2 conversion nearly was constant but CO conversion from CZA-2.5 to CZA-5 was drastically dropped. In the case of H2/CO2 feed, the situation is different. By comparing Figs. 5b and 10 b, CZA-0 and CZA-2.5 showed more drop in activity in H2/CO2 feed compared to H2/CO/CO2 feed and the others showed higher stability in H2/CO2 feed. As a matter of fact, H2/CO2 feed has more oxidizing properties than H2/CO/CO2 feed and in this environment, there is no CO to recover active copper sites and Cu+/Cu° cycles are disrupted so that the CO hydrogenation is decreased because of the mentioned reason. However, by increasing In2O3 the CO2 hydrogenation regime became dominant and we observed that the CZA-5, CZ-7.5 and pure In2O3 in H2/CO2 feed are more stable and have reached to steady-state with a faster rate than the observed rate in the H2/CO/CO2 feed. Probably in the later feed, strong adsorption of CO2 on the reduced copper decreases the CO hydrogenation gradually and hence reaching to steady-state is longer than H2/CO2 feed. In addition, for CZA-0 and CZA-2.5 another point is about the stability of indium containing samples in H2/CO2 feed. In H2/CO2 feed, indium containing samples showed higher stabilities than the H2/CO/CO2 feed and for pure In2O3, the STY is nearly the same for both feed. In addition, in H2/CO2 feed, pure In2O3 showed remarkable activity in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. In this regard, it can be stated that pure In2O3 could hydrogenate the CO2 without the aid of CO. In other words, In2O3 does not hydrogenate the CO and instead, it can hydrogenate the CO2 directly. Actually, one of the main disadvantages of ternary CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst in direct CO2 hydrogenation is the rapid decrease in catalyst activity. This issue is seen in Fig. 10b. Against the ternary CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst, pure In2O3 can directly hydrogenate the CO2 to methanol with 100 % selectivity and remarkable stability; but one of the major disadvantages, in this case, is the low CO2 hydrogenation rate and consequently lower methanol production. Based on CO2-TPD results pure In2O3 also showed strong CO2 adsorption. This strong adsorption provides a suitable condition for hydrogenation to methanol; but it should be noted that strong adsorption of CO2 is not sufficient and moreover strong adsorption, dissociative adsorption and finally spill-over of hydrogen species on the surface is necessary. For this purpose, Pd seems to be a suitable candidate since it has been used as a promoter for its role in spillover ability and its activity in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [32]. We prepared Pd/In2O3 catalyst by impregnation method as mentioned in the experimental section wherein the total Pd amount was 1 wt.%. Similar to other samples, this catalyst was reduced in a reducing gas mixture (5 % H2 in 95 % N2) at 240 °C and atmospheric pressure for 12 h and tested at 50 bar and 250 °C in H2/CO2 (80:20) feed. The textural and catalytic properties of the In2O3 and Pd/In2O3 are listed in Table 3 . According to Table 3, Vb and SBET decreased after impregnation, due to the pore filling with the Pd particles. Fig. 12 a and b illustrate the H2-TPR and CO2-TPD results for both In2O3 and Pd/In2O3 catalysts. The reduction of pure In2O3 starts at around 150 °C. Two peaks centered at 200 °C and 320 °C are related to the In2O3 reduction at the surface. The mentioned peaks also could be assigned to the oxygen vacancy formation [14]. TPR profile of the Pd/In2O3 is similar to pure In2O3 except a low-temperature peak centered around 40 °C was observed, which is related to the reduction of PdO [33]. It is seen that in the presence of Pd, reduction onset of In2O3 shifted to lower temperatures as a shoulder peak which in turn helps to generate oxygen vacancies, and ultimately boosts the dissociation of hydrogen and improves spillover effect [34]. Fig. 12b demonstrates the CO2-TPD for In2O3 and Pd/In2O3 catalysts. Low-temperature desorption peak could be attributed to physically adsorbed CO2. The peak around 650 °C for In2O3 arises from CO2 adsorption in the thermally induced oxygen vacancy sites [14]. In the case of Pd/In2O3 catalyst, an additional peak appears around 320 °C. It is believed that this peak is related to oxygen vacancy generation caused by H2 reduction [14]. It means that, two different sites for CO2 adsorption were formed in Pd/In2O3 catalyst. Based on the Sabatier principle, if adsorption of reactants to the surface is too strong, the adsorbates will be unable to desorb from the surface resulting in a low production rate. In pure In2O3, strong adsorption of CO2 on the surface has resulted in lower methanol production rate. Based on Fig. 12b, the creation of the lower temperature CO2 adsorption sites in palladium-containing catalyst can improve the performance of the Pd/In2O3 catalyst. In addition to the creation of new CO2 adsorption sites, palladium is also active in CO2 hydrogenation and could provide hydrogen atom efficiently due to its spillover ability. This is consistent with the obtained catalytic test. Based on the results in Table 3, for the Pd/In2O3 catalyst both CO2 conversion and STY increased significantly than those observed in pure In2O3. Higher methanol production rates in direct hydrogenation of CO2 for Pd/In2O3 catalysts is the result of higher oxygen vacancies, improved adsorption of CO2 (lower adsorption in presence of Pd) and spillover ability of palladium along with its role in CO2 hydrogenation. Finally, the stability test for Pd/In2O3 was performed and the comparison results are plotted in Fig. 13 . As can be seen in Fig. 13, palladium improved the activity of In2O3 catalyst even higher than CZA-5. In addition, the stability of the catalyst seems to be higher than CZA-2.5. The In2O3 ability in direct hydrogenation of CO2 makes this substance a good candidate for mitigation of CO2 and its conversion into methanol. However, some modifications should be exerted to enhance its activity toward direct hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. 4 Conclusion The effect of indium addition on the textural properties and catalytic performance of a ternary CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst in methanol synthesis at 50 bar and 250 °C was investigated. The catalysts were evaluated under different feed compositions containing H2/CO/CO2, H2/CO, and H2/CO2. The results indicated the promotional effects of indium addition on the structural properties. The addition of indium increased the BET area and Cu surface area and decreased the Cu crystallite sizes and led to the higher oxygen vacancies. However, the activity results showed a decrease in methanol production in catalysts containing indium oxide and the increment in indium content decreased the methanol production rate. The results showed that the In2O3 severely affected the CO2 adsorption and made it stronger which in turn caused the drastic drop in catalytic activity in H2/CO/CO2 feed. This drastic drop was because of suppressing CO hydrogenation to methanol and shifting the hydrogenation regime from CO hydrogenation (faster reaction) to CO2 hydrogenation (slower reaction). In H2/CO2 feed, the samples containing higher amounts of In2O3 showed higher stability. In addition, In2O3 can directly hydrogenate the CO2 to methanol; but because of very strong adsorption of CO2, the conversion rate of CO2 to methanol is low. Addition of palladium enhanced the catalytic activity remarkably. The higher activity of Pd/In2O3 compared to the pure In2O3 likely is due to strong spillover ability of palladium in hydrogen dissociation along with the creation of CO2 adsorption sites with milder adsorption than the pure In2O3. coredata.dc:description: Ternary CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst was synthesized through coprecipitation method and the effect of indium addition on the textural and catalytic performance was evaluated. The catalysts were tested at 50 atm and 250 °C in H2/CO/CO2, H2/CO and H2/CO2 feed. The presence of In2O3 resulted in structural promotions including enhanced BET and copper surface area, smaller copper crystals and increased oxygen vacancies. On the contrary, unexpected results were observed in catalytic activities in H2/CO/CO2 and H2/CO2 feeds. Pure In2O3 revealed the ability of direct hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. In addition, it was observed that the addition of palladium into the catalyst remarkably enhanced the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of In2O3 on the structural properties and catalytic performance of the CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst in CO2 and CO hydrogenation to methanol
